attributes.title: Efficacy and safety of acupoint catgut embedding for irritable bowel syndrome: protocol for a systematic review and meta analysis
attributes.description: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a group of continuous or intermittent attacks, which is characterized by abdominal pain, abdominal distention, defecation habits and / or changes in stool characteristics, but lack of gastrointestinal structure and biochemical abnormalities. Rome III classified it as a kind of functional enteropathy, the patients were mainly young and middle-aged people, the age of onset was more in 20-50 years old, women were more than men, there was a tendency of family aggregation, often accompanied by other gastrointestinal disorders such as functional dyspepsia. According to the characteristics of stool, IBS can be divided into four clinical types: diarrhea type, constipation type, mixed type and atypical type. acupoint catgut embedding in the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on acupoint catgut embedding for irritable bowel syndrome. Therefore, research on it is needed.

q1.value: Efficacy and safety of acupoint catgut embedding for irritable bowel syndrome: a systematic review and meta analysis

q2.value: Jing Wu, Shasha Yang, Qinwei Fu, Qinxiu Zhang, Hui Wang, Yao Fengli

q3.value: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a group of continuous or intermittent attacks, which is characterized by abdominal pain, abdominal distention, defecation habits and / or changes in stool characteristics, but lack of gastrointestinal structure and biochemical abnormalities. Rome III classified it as a kind of functional enteropathy, the patients were mainly young and middle-aged people, the age of onset was more in 20-50 years old, women were more than men, there was a tendency of family aggregation, often accompanied by other gastrointestinal disorders such as functional dyspepsia. According to the characteristics of stool, IBS can be divided into four clinical types: diarrhea type, constipation type, mixed type and atypical type. acupoint catgut embedding in the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on acupoint catgut embedding for irritable bowel syndrome. Therefore, research on it is needed.

q4.value:
1. acupoint catgut embedding is effective for treatment of patients with irritable bowel syndrome.
2. How does the efficacy of acupoint catgut embedding compare to that with Western medicine therapies alone, other TCM therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. There are some moderating variables associated with prevention and treatment efficacy in studies of acupoint catgut embedding for patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value:
Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.
Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.

The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

question.value:
1. Anticipated start date: 02/14/2020;

2. Anticipated completion date: 05/20/2020;

3.Review question: ①. Is acupoint catgut embedding an effective treatment for patiens with irritable bowel syndrome?
                ②. How does the efficacy and safety of acupoint catgut embedding compare to that with fake acupoint catgut embedding, normal acupuncture, western medicine, fire needle acupuncture, auricular point therapy, blank control, placebo control and other interventions?
                ③. What moderating variables are associated with treatment effectiveness in studies of acupoint catgut embedding for patients with irritable bowel syndrome? 

4. Searches: English databases including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library and Chinese databases including CNKI, Wanfang, VIP databases will be searched. The research will start following the PRISMA protocol.

The terms used in the search will follow the rules of the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and the question that guided the search was based on the PICOS strategy (participants, interventions, comparison, results and studies). The following search strategy terms will be included: ①"Irritable bowel syndrome" or "IBS" or "Changyijizonghezheng(肠易激综合征)"; ② "acupoint catgut embedding" or "catgut embedding therapy" or "catgut implantation at acupoint" or "point embedding therapy" or "Maixian(埋线)".
One month will be allocated for data collection and one month for article analysis.
Retrieval time is from the inception dates of the databases to Feb 29, 2020.
We also considered the alternative terms and spellings for keywords.
In addition, the references of initially included literature were traced back to achieve a comprehensive search. English and Chinese language were included.
Additional search strategy information can be found in the attached PDF document (link provided below).

5. Condition or domain being studied: Condition or domain being studied: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a group of continuous or intermittent attacks, which is characterized by abdominal pain, abdominal distention, defecation habits and / or changes in stool characteristics, but lack of gastrointestinal structure and biochemical abnormalities. Rome III classified it as a kind of functional enteropathy, the patients were mainly young and middle-aged people, the age of onset was more in 20-50 years old, women were more than men, there was a tendency of family aggregation, often accompanied by other gastrointestinal disorders such as functional dyspepsia. According to the characteristics of stool, IBS can be divided into four clinical types: diarrhea type, constipation type, mixed type and atypical type. acupoint catgut embedding in the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on acupoint catgut embedding for irritable bowel syndrome. Therefore, research on it is needed.

6.Participants/population: Patients with diagnosed IBS will be included, regardless of gender, age, race, education status, cases of source and different subtypes of IBS.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Intervention measures will be either acupoint catgut embedding alone or combined with other methods.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Fake acupoint catgut embedding, normal acupuncture, western medicine, fire needle acupuncture, auricular point therapy, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): ①Scores of the IBS Adequate Relief question;
                   ②IBS-SSS; 
                   ③Total effective rate; 

11. Additional outcome(s): ① Evaluation index of enterodynamic effect;
                       ②Evaluation index of intestinal accommodation function;
③Psychological assessment scale;
④Evaluation index of TCM diagnosis and treatment;

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

16. Type and method of review: intervention; Meta-analysis; Systematic review.

17. Health area of the review: Complementary therapies; Digestive system; Public health; 

18. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

19. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

q1.value: Efficacy of Treatments to Improve Vulvar, introit or vestibule atrophy: A Systematic Review.

q3.value: Vulvar atrophy is a common condition generally associated with vaginal and urinary atrophy although rarely separated from them. Symptoms include irritation, itching, soreness, burning, and dyspareunia, and has a substantial effect on quality of life. There are numerous treatments for vaginal atrophy but there is little medical literature on the effectiveness of treatments for vulvar atrophy and its consequences. Our objective is to analyzed the efficacy of treatments for improving the vulvar, introit or vestibular atrophy in postmenopausal women?

q4.value: Not any treatment for vaginal atrophy improve vulvar, introit or vestibular atrophy

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: In order to identify eligible articles, we will perform a systematic review of the literature.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
In order to identify eligible articles, we will perform a systematic review of the literature. The  following databases will be searched: MEDLINE (via PubMed), The Cochrane Library (CENTRAL),  and SCOPUS, from their inception until the most recent date. 
We  will  design  a  search  strategy,  tailored  to  the  requirements  of  each  database,  which  will include  a  combination  of  controlled  vocabulary  and search  terms  related  to  each  clinical  question and the associated inclusion criteria. When necessary, validated filters will be also used to retrieve the appropriate designs. 
Additional studies will be identified by hand searching of reference lists of relevant studies or reviews identified. Initially, no restrictions will be applied in terms of language, date or status of publication. We will report the process of study se lection in a PRISMA flowchart.
	
Types of study to be included 
It is expected to find various types of study designs, providing data on the outcomes of interest for the review. We will consider other systematic reviews addressing the clinical questions and providing relevant data for our review. In addition, we will include both randomized controlled trials (RCTs), extension studies and follow up reports of trials and sound observational studies, which have not been included in previous reviews or those providing compelling data for the purposes of our reviews. 
We will consider those observational studies with a minimum quality of the analyzed data (large clinical registers or administrative data, nationwide cohorts, prospective follow up studies, or large case control studies).

Participants/population 
Postmenopausal women  of  any  age,  with  any  of  the  conditions  of  interest  to  the  review and receiving (or candidates to receive) local o systemic therapy for vulvar atrophy. 

Intervention(s), exposure(s) 
Any type of treatments (drugs or physical treatments) with different formulations and routes of administration.
	
Comparator(s)/control 
Placebo or no treatment; different treatment durations; any drugs compared to each other. 

Context 
Any context; however, it is reasonable to consider that treatment will be administered mostly on ambulatory (community) basis. 

Primary outcome(s) 
Efficacy and security of each treatment
if the condition allows we will do meta-analysis

question.value: We wish to determine if perception can be influenced by physical conditions. The control group will sit 5 feet from a water bottle and will be asked to determine how far away from them the water is. The experimental group will will sit in the same place but will be given a cup of 10 pretzels. After they have eaten the pretzels, they will then be asked to judge how far away from them the water is.

question.value: We are only manipulating one variable: pretzel consumption. The control group will not be given pretzels to eat and the experimental group will be given pretzels to eat.
We will measure how thirsty the person feels on a likert scale of 1-5, and we will measure how far they believe the water to be in feet/ inches.
We would use the ANOVA model because we are imputing three different variables: thirstiness rating, perceived distance of water, and weather or not they eat pretzles.

comments.value:
General Information

This is a replication project being completed by an undergraduate Experimental Psychology course at Yeshiva University. A total of 18 undergraduate students and 3 graduate student instructors are contributing to the project, in addition to the PI (Lisa Chalik).

Abstract (from Griskevicius et al.)

Why do people purchase proenvironmental “green” products? We argue that buying such products can be construed as altruistic, since green products often cost more and are of lower quality than their conventional counterparts, but green goods benefit the environment for everyone. Because biologists have observed that altruism might function as a “costly signal” associated with status, we examined in 3 experiments how status motives influenced desire for green products. Activating status motives led people to choose green products over more luxurious nongreen products. Supporting the notion that altruism signals one’s willingness and ability to incur costs for others’ benefit, status motives increased desire for green products when shopping in public (but not private) and when green products cost more (but not less) than nongreen products. Findings suggest that status competition can be used to promote proenvironmental behavior.

Planned Methods

This will be a replication of the original study, the only deviation being that participants will complete the study online, through Qualtrics. We will collect a minimum N of 100 participants. These participants will be recruited through word-of-mouth, and will likely consist mostly of friends and family of the students conducting the project.

For exploratory purposes, we have also added some demographic questions at the end of the procedure.

attributes.title: FEEL - Feminity and Emotions in Leadership

q1.value: Gender stereotypes concerning the emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of managers with reference to a transformational leadership style

q2.value: Denise Dörfel, Anika Ihmels, Madita Brandhorst

q3.value:
Today, the picture of women in leadership positions is slowly beginning to change, for example most Americans no longer prefer a male to a female boss (Brenan, 2017). One reason for this shift in perspective might be differences in leadership styles between men and women (Miller & Adkins, 2016). This is underlined by the finding that there actually are perceived gender differences in leadership styles (Eagly & Carli, 2003). Eagly and Carli’s meta-analysis shows, inter alia, that transformational leadership is perceived to be more typical for female than for male leaders. And transformational leadership does not only include an emotional component through leader-member-exchange (Little, Gooty & Williams, 2016; Glasø & Einarsen, 2008), but is also strongly linked to performance outcomes (Ng, 2017). But even though there is positive evidence for the success of female leadership, there are still barriers for women to succeed in leadership positions (Brescoll, 2016). One reason for this are gender stereotypes as described by Schein (1975) with the think manager – think male phenomenon more than 40 years ago. A recent study by Fischbach, Lichtenthaler & Horstman (2015) extended Schein’s paradigm to the area of emotion expression and showed that gender stereotypes still hold true when it comes to female leaders and emotions. Additionally, there is evidence for gender differences in the use of emotion regulation strategies: LaFrance and Banaji (1992) describe how using suppression for negative emotions is more socially acceptable for males and Gross and John (2003) found that men are more likely to use suppression than women. Further, Shields (2005) applies the use of emotion regulation strategies to the workplace and denotes that “[i]n most workplaces the economical expressiveness of manly emotion is the standard (…)” (ibid., p. 11). However, the effect of gender stereotypes concerning the typical emotion regulation strategies and especially the role of a transformational leadership style within emotion management remain rather unclear. Based on these findings, the aim of this study is to 1) replicate the findings of Fischbach et al. (2015) regarding gender stereotypes concerning emotion expression of successful managers, men and women, 2) to extend the think manager – think male investigation to different emotion regulation strategies and 3) to investigate the role of a transformational leadership style regarding gender stereotypes about emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies.

Research Questions 
1. Which gender stereotypes exist with regard to the perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of successful managers? 

2. Which role does a transformational leadership style play in view of gender stereotypes with regard to the perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of successful managers?

3. Which role does a transformational leadership style play in view of the overall perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of successful managers?

q4.value:
1. Hypotheses about gender stereotypes with regard to the perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of successful managers:

• H1.1a: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived expression of emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived expression of emotions of women and successful managers.
• H1.1b: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived expression of achievement emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived expression of achievement emotions of women and successful managers.
• H1.1c: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived expression of approach emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived expression of approach emotions of women and successful managers.
• H1.1d: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived expression of antagonistic emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived expression of antagonistic emotions of women and successful managers.
• H1.1e: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived expression of resignation emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived expression of resignation emotions of women and successful managers.

• H1.2a: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived suppression of emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived suppression of emotions of women and successful managers.
• H1.2b: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived suppression of achievement emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived suppression of achievement emotions of women and successful managers.
• H1.2c: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived suppression of approach emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived suppression of approach emotions of women and successful managers.
• H1.2d: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived suppression of antagonistic emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived suppression of antagonistic emotions of women and successful managers.
• H1.2e: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived suppression of resignation emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived suppression of resignation emotions of women and successful managers.

• H1.3a: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived reappraisal of emotions of women and successful managers than regarding the perceived reappraisal of emotions of men and successful managers.
• H1.3b: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived reappraisal of achievement emotions of men and successful managers than regarding the perceived reappraisal of achievement emotions of women and successful managers.
• H1.3c: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived reappraisal of approach emotions of women and successful managers than regarding the perceived reappraisal of approach emotions of men and successful managers.
• H1.3d: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived reappraisal of antagonistic emotions of women and successful managers than regarding the perceived reappraisal of antagonistic emotions of men and successful managers.
• H1.3e: There is a higher correspondence regarding the perceived reappraisal of resignation emotions of women and successful managers than regarding the perceived reappraisal of resignation emotions of men and successful managers.


2. Hypotheses regarding the role of a transformational leadership style in view of gender stereotypes with regard to the perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of successful managers

• H2.1: Women are perceived as more lacking the emotion expression of successful managers when no further information is provided about a leadership style. When successful managers are described including information about their transformational leadership style, women are more frequently perceived as exhibiting 
  - H2.1a: the expression of emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.1b: the expression of achievement emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.1c: the expression of approach emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.1d: the expression of antagonistic emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.1e: the expression of resignation emotions of successful managers.

• H2.2: Women are perceived as more lacking the emotion suppression of successful managers when no further information is provided about a leadership style. When successful managers are described including information about their transformational leadership style, women are more frequently perceived as exhibiting 
  - H2.2a: the suppression of emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.2b: the suppression of achievement emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.2c: the suppression of approach emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.2d: the suppression of antagonistic emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.2e: the suppression of resignation emotions of successful managers.

• H2.3: In general, women are perceived as showing the emotion reappraisal of successful managers even when no further information is provided about a leadership style. However, when successful managers are described including information about their transformational leadership style, women are even more frequently perceived as exhibiting 
  - H2.3a: the reappraisal of emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.3b: the reappraisal of achievement emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.3c: the reappraisal of approach emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.3d: the reappraisal of antagonistic emotions of successful managers.
  - H2.3e: the reappraisal of resignation emotions of successful managers.


3. Hypotheses regarding the role of a transformational leadership style in view of the overall perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of successful managers:

• H3.1: Emotion expression is perceived to be more characteristic for successful managers who are described including information about their transformational leadership style than for successful managers in general.
• H3.2: Emotion suppression is perceived to be less characteristic for successful managers who are described including information about their transformational leadership style than for successful managers in general.
• H3.3: Emotion reappraisal is perceived to be more characteristic for successful managers who are described including information about their transformational leadership style than for successful managers in general.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional online survey, mixed design with between-subject factors (group allocation) and within-subject factors (emotion expression and regulation strategies)

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups by a SosciSurvey (https://www.soscisurvey.de/) algorithm according to the number of participants per group and the participant’s gender to ensure equal group sizes. Each participant will evaluate only one of four targets regarding characteristic emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies: women in general, men in general, successful managers in general or successful managers who are described including information about their transformational leadership style (“transformational managers”).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
- This study will be based on a convenience sample and will therefore not be representative 
  for a specific population.
- Participants will be recruited through professional contacts, social media (Facebook, XING 
  and LinkedIn), SurveyCircle and an internal subject recruitment platform at the Faculty of 
  Psychology, Technical University Dresden (“Zentraler Experimentalserver”, ZEP).
- Participants will not be paid for filling out the survey.
- Participants must be at least 18 years old, be German native speakers and to be currently
  employed (incl. internship etc.).
- Data collection will take place in March 2020.

q13.value: The target sample size is 310 participants, who will be randomly assigned to one of four groups.

q14.value:
Research questions 1 and 2 are to be investigated using Intraclass Correlation Coefficients. However, there is hardly any rationale for a minimum sample size for this method. Here, the findings of Schönbrodt and Perugini (2013) will serve as a point of reference. They recommend aiming for a sample size of 250 participants to reach stable coefficients.

Research question 3 will be investigated using an ANOVA. Therefore, an a priori power analysis using G*Power 3.1.9.4 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang & Buchner, 2007) for Max OS X was conducted for a 2 x 4 fixed effects ANOVA with main effects and interactions. The numbers of groups for the power analysis was 2 (comparing successful managers in general against successful managers who are described including a transformational leadership style) and the degrees of freedom (df) were 3 (based on 4 different emotion classes). 
A medium effect size (f) of 0,25 was chosen and a targeted power of 0,95. The a priori analysis revealed a required sample size of 279 participants to reach an actual power of 0,9502729.
To account for incomplete data and terminations, the estimated sample size was increased by around 10% of the suggested sample size, leading to a target sample size of 310 participants.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated as soon as the target sample size of 310 participants is reached. However, due to involvement of a student’s master thesis data analysis will already begin after three weeks of data collection, even if the targeted sample size may not be reached at that point.

question.value: Group allocation: each participant will be randomly assigned to one of four target groups (women in general, men in general, successful managers in general, successful managers who are described including information about their transformational leadership style = “transformational managers”) and rate the respective group regarding the perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies.

Emotion Regulation Index (based on Fischbach et al., 2015): 
1) “How characteristic do you think expressing the following emotions is for [target group]?” 
2) “How characteristic do you think suppressing the following emotions is for [target group]?” 
3) “How characteristic do you think reappraising a situation in which the following emotions are felt is for [target group]? 

- Pride
- Joy
- Elation
- Satisfaction
- Relief
- Hope
- Interest
- Surprise
- Envy
- Outrage
- Contempt
- Rage
- Anger
- Sadness
- Fear
- Shame
- Guilt

(51 items, 5-point scale from 1 = not characteristic to 5 = characteristic)

Demographic questions: Age, Gender (male, female, non-binary/diverse), Educational level / degree, Occupation in general, Occupation for students, Weekly working time (in hours, incl. regular overtime), Field of work / industry / sector, General management responsibility (yes / no) 

Leadership questions (if General management responsibility = yes): Management level, Management experience (in years), Specific management responsibility (number of employees managed)

Female role model questions: Socialization (east vs. west Germany), occupation of mother during childhood (working full-time / part-time, not working)

Emotion Regulation questions (based on the ERQ; Gross & John, 2003) for specific emotions (anger, shame, prime, guilt, joy, sadness) to measure whether participants themselves use the two emotion regulation strategies suppression and reappraisal (7-point scale from 1 = strongly disagree to 7 = strongly agree). For this study, emotion-specific item version will be used which were developed based on the German version of the ERQ by Abler & Kessler (2009).

Bem Sex-Role Inventory (BSRI-R; Troche & Rammsayer, 2011) to measure participants’ masculinity / femininity (30 items, 7-point scale from 1 = never or almost never to 7 = always)

Gender-role Orientation Scale (GRO; Krampen, 1983) to measure participants’ gender-role   orientation (52 items, 7-point scale from 1 = very wrong to 7 = very right)

1. Emotion Expression Indices: mean of the ratings for emotion expression per target group (men in general, women in general, successful managers in general, transformational managers)
  - one index for all 17 emotions
  - one index for each of the four emotion classes 
    (Achievement emotions = pride, joy, elation, satisfaction; Approach emotions = relief, hope,
    interest, surprise; Antagonistic emotions = envy, outrage/disgust, contempt, rage, anger; Resignation emotions = sadness, fear, shame, guilt)

2. Emotion Suppression Indices: mean of the ratings for emotion suppression per target group (men in general, women in general, successful managers, transformational managers) 
  - one index for all 17 measured emotions
  - one index for each of the four emotion classes 
    (Achievement emotions; Approach emotions; Antagonistic emotions; Resignation emotions)

3. Emotion Reappraisal Indices: mean of the ratings for emotion reappraisal per target group (men in general, women in general, successful managers, transformational managers) 
  - one index for all 17 measured emotions
  - one index for each of the four emotion classes 
    (Achievement emotions; Approach emotions; Antagonistic emotions; Resignation emotions)

4. Gender-role orientation: the ratings are summed up to an unweighted index ranging from extreme non-traditional to extreme traditional

5. Bem Sex-Role Inventory: scores for Femininity and Masculinity are being computed based on 15 items representing characteristics more socially acceptable for women / men

1. Similarity between groups: Intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs) are calculated separately for the emotion expression, suppression and reappraisal indices to determine the degree of similarity of the following groups:
- Women in general and successful managers in general
- Men in general and successful managers in general 
- Women in general and “transformational managers”

2. Differences between groups: ANOVAs will be calculated to investigate differences in perceived emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies between successful managers in general and successful managers who are described including information about their transformational leadership style

q21.value: A p-value of 0,05 will be used to determine inferences regarding the significance of results.

q22.value: To check for compliance and proper questionnaire completion, manipulation checks will be included after the question for 1) expression of emotions, 2) suppression of emotions and 3) reappraisal of emotional situations. Participants will have to answer whether they just rated emotional expression, suppression or situational reappraisal and will also be asked to state which target group (women in general, men in general, successful managers in general, successful managers with a specific leadership style) they just answered for. Participants failing the manipulation checks will be excluded from analysis due to lacking compliance.

q23.value: Participants who did not complete at least 75% of the questionnaire incl. the ratings for emotion expression, emotion suppression and emotion reappraisal will be excluded from analysis.

q24.value:
To further investigate research questions 3, the impact of the different emotion classes achievement, approach, antagonistic and resignation emotions will be explored for the perceived difference between successful managers and “transformational managers” with regard to…
1) emotional expression, 
2) emotional suppression and
3) emotional reappraisal.

Additionally, the influence of the following constructs will be explored with regard to
1) gender stereotypes (research questions 1 and 2), as well as
2) the role of leadership style (research question 3): 
  - Gender (male / female / non-binary)
  - Leadership Experience: “Are you currently in a leadership position” (yes / no)
  - Gender-role Orientation Scale (GRO; Krampen, 1983): non-traditional vs. traditional 
  - Bem Sex-Role Inventory (BSRI-R; Troche & Rammsayer, 2011): masculinity / femininity
  - Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (based on the ERQ; Gross & John, 2003; German version 
    by Abler & Kessler, 2009): use of emotion-specific suppression / reappraisal 
  - Female role model (based on spending most of their childhood in former east vs. west
    Germany, having a working mother or not)

registration_responses.q1: Gender stereotypes concerning the emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of managers with reference to a transformational leadership style
registration_responses.q2: Denise Dörfel, Anika Ihmels, Madita Brandhorst
registration_responses.q3:
Today, the picture of women in leadership positions is slowly beginning to change, for example most Americans no longer prefer a male to a female boss (Brenan, 2017). One reason for this shift in perspective might be differences in leadership styles between men and women (Miller & Adkins, 2016). This is underlined by the finding that there actually are perceived gender differences in leadership styles (Eagly & Carli, 2003). Eagly and Carli’s meta-analysis shows, inter alia, that transformational leadership is perceived to be more typical for female than for male leaders. And transformational leadership does not only include an emotional component through leader-member-exchange (Little, Gooty & Williams, 2016; Glasø & Einarsen, 2008), but is also strongly linked to performance outcomes (Ng, 2017). But even though there is positive evidence for the success of female leadership, there are still barriers for women to succeed in leadership positions (Brescoll, 2016). One reason for this are gender stereotypes as described by Schein (1975) with the think manager – think male phenomenon more than 40 years ago. A recent study by Fischbach, Lichtenthaler & Horstman (2015) extended Schein’s paradigm to the area of emotion expression and showed that gender stereotypes still hold true when it comes to female leaders and emotions. Additionally, there is evidence for gender differences in the use of emotion regulation strategies: LaFrance and Banaji (1992) describe how using suppression for negative emotions is more socially acceptable for males and Gross and John (2003) found that men are more likely to use suppression than women. Further, Shields (2005) applies the use of emotion regulation strategies to the workplace and denotes that “[i]n most workplaces the economical expressiveness of manly emotion is the standard (…)” (ibid., p. 11). However, the effect of gender stereotypes concerning the typical emotion regulation strategies and especially the role of a transformational leadership style within emotion management remain rather unclear. Based on these findings, the aim of this study is to 1) replicate the findings of Fischbach et al. (2015) regarding gender stereotypes concerning emotion expression of successful managers, men and women, 2) to extend the think manager – think male investigation to different emotion regulation strategies and 3) to investigate the role of a transformational leadership style regarding gender stereotypes about emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies.

Research Questions 
1. Which gender stereotypes exist with regard to the perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of successful managers? 

2. Which role does a transformational leadership style play in view of gender stereotypes with regard to the perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of successful managers?

3. Which role does a transformational leadership style play in view of the overall perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies of successful managers?

Troche, S., & Rammsayer, T. H. (2011). Eine Revision des deutschsprachigen Bem Sex-Role Inventory. Klinische Diagnostik und Evaluation, 4, 262-283.
registration_responses.q8.question: Cross-sectional online survey, mixed design with between-subject factors (group allocation) and within-subject factors (emotion expression and regulation strategies)
registration_responses.q12.question:
- This study will be based on a convenience sample and will therefore not be representative 
  for a specific population.
- Participants will be recruited through professional contacts, social media (Facebook, XING 
  and LinkedIn), SurveyCircle and an internal subject recruitment platform at the Faculty of 
  Psychology, Technical University Dresden (“Zentraler Experimentalserver”, ZEP).
- Participants will not be paid for filling out the survey.
- Participants must be at least 18 years old, be German native speakers and to be currently
  employed (incl. internship etc.).
- Data collection will take place in March 2020.
registration_responses.q16.question: Group allocation: each participant will be randomly assigned to one of four target groups (women in general, men in general, successful managers in general, successful managers who are described including information about their transformational leadership style = “transformational managers”) and rate the respective group regarding the perception of emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Emotion Regulation Index (based on Fischbach et al., 2015): 
1) “How characteristic do you think expressing the following emotions is for [target group]?” 
2) “How characteristic do you think suppressing the following emotions is for [target group]?” 
3) “How characteristic do you think reappraising a situation in which the following emotions are felt is for [target group]? 

- Pride
- Joy
- Elation
- Satisfaction
- Relief
- Hope
- Interest
- Surprise
- Envy
- Outrage
- Contempt
- Rage
- Anger
- Sadness
- Fear
- Shame
- Guilt

(51 items, 5-point scale from 1 = not characteristic to 5 = characteristic)

Demographic questions: Age, Gender (male, female, non-binary/diverse), Educational level / degree, Occupation in general, Occupation for students, Weekly working time (in hours, incl. regular overtime), Field of work / industry / sector, General management responsibility (yes / no) 

Leadership questions (if General management responsibility = yes): Management level, Management experience (in years), Specific management responsibility (number of employees managed)

Female role model questions: Socialization (east vs. west Germany), occupation of mother during childhood (working full-time / part-time, not working)

Emotion Regulation questions (based on the ERQ; Gross & John, 2003) for specific emotions (anger, shame, prime, guilt, joy, sadness) to measure whether participants themselves use the two emotion regulation strategies suppression and reappraisal (7-point scale from 1 = strongly disagree to 7 = strongly agree). For this study, emotion-specific item version will be used which were developed based on the German version of the ERQ by Abler & Kessler (2009).

Bem Sex-Role Inventory (BSRI-R; Troche & Rammsayer, 2011) to measure participants’ masculinity / femininity (30 items, 7-point scale from 1 = never or almost never to 7 = always)

Gender-role Orientation Scale (GRO; Krampen, 1983) to measure participants’ gender-role   orientation (52 items, 7-point scale from 1 = very wrong to 7 = very right)
registration_responses.q18.question:
1. Emotion Expression Indices: mean of the ratings for emotion expression per target group (men in general, women in general, successful managers in general, transformational managers)
  - one index for all 17 emotions
  - one index for each of the four emotion classes 
    (Achievement emotions = pride, joy, elation, satisfaction; Approach emotions = relief, hope,
    interest, surprise; Antagonistic emotions = envy, outrage/disgust, contempt, rage, anger; Resignation emotions = sadness, fear, shame, guilt)

2. Emotion Suppression Indices: mean of the ratings for emotion suppression per target group (men in general, women in general, successful managers, transformational managers) 
  - one index for all 17 measured emotions
  - one index for each of the four emotion classes 
    (Achievement emotions; Approach emotions; Antagonistic emotions; Resignation emotions)

3. Emotion Reappraisal Indices: mean of the ratings for emotion reappraisal per target group (men in general, women in general, successful managers, transformational managers) 
  - one index for all 17 measured emotions
  - one index for each of the four emotion classes 
    (Achievement emotions; Approach emotions; Antagonistic emotions; Resignation emotions)

4. Gender-role orientation: the ratings are summed up to an unweighted index ranging from extreme non-traditional to extreme traditional

5. Bem Sex-Role Inventory: scores for Femininity and Masculinity are being computed based on 15 items representing characteristics more socially acceptable for women / men
registration_responses.q19.question:
1. Similarity between groups: Intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs) are calculated separately for the emotion expression, suppression and reappraisal indices to determine the degree of similarity of the following groups:
- Women in general and successful managers in general
- Men in general and successful managers in general 
- Women in general and “transformational managers”

2. Differences between groups: ANOVAs will be calculated to investigate differences in perceived emotion expression and emotion regulation strategies between successful managers in general and successful managers who are described including information about their transformational leadership style

attributes.title: Temporal Bias
attributes.description: We're interested in how events that raise the salience of race affect rates of economic discrimination.

q2.value: Peter Younkin, Gordon Burtch, Andreea Gorbatai

q3.value: We are interested in the degree to which (seemingly unrelated) external events shape discriminatory economic activity.  The purpose is to integrate research in social psychology that has demonstrated the variability of bias with work in sociology and economics that has treated discriminatory acts as either about information or innate prejudice.  Our hope is to provide some insight into when economic acts are susceptible to changes in the general salience of racial divisions.

q4.value:
H1: Increasing the salience of race negatively affects how individuals appraise Black founders.

H2: White respondents will be more likely than black respondent to penalize Black founders in the wake of an increase in salience.

H3: The effect of an increase in salience will diminish with time, such that subjects will be less likely to discount Black founders 4hrs after the event than they would be 1hr after.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We will be conducting two experiments in sequence. Both use the same basic format but vary in one particular detail.  For both experiments we will hire people via Prolific to "assist with analysis of web content."  Each respondent will be paid for their participation and the project was approved by our local IRB.  Upon acceptance of the task, each respondent will see a newspaper article, a product review,  and a crowdfunding project and were asked a series of identical questions (detailed below) about each site. The experiment employs a 2x2 between-subject design to compare the effect of priming racial divisions on evaluations of Black and non-Black crowdfunding founders. Specifically, the respondents will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions (Control, Unprimed-Black, Primed-non-Black, Primed-Black) corresponding to the newspaper article and the race of the founder they were shown (all subjects evaluate the same product review). In the Control condition, the respondents will be asked to evaluate the grammar and quality of an article about a Spring snowstorm affecting the Midwestern United States. They will then be shown a product review for a waterproof smartphone case and asked to evaluate the usefulness and grammar of the review. Finally, they will see a crowdfunding project for a waterproof portable speaker by a white founder named ‘Joe M.’ and asked to evaluate its quality and the likelihood of success. The respondents in the Unprimed-Black condition receive the identical set of projects and questions with one variation: the photograph and name of the founder is changed to a Black man named ‘Malik M.’ Thus, one treatment in this experiment is variation in the signaled race of a founder, with the project held constant. The evaluations arising from these two conditions helped to establish a baseline of perceived quality for non-Black and Black founders in the unprimed state.
	The principal treatment involved variation in the priming of racial divisions. Therefore, respondents in the two Primed conditions received a sequence of website content and questions identical to those in the Unprimed conditions with one exception: the first article they are asked to evaluate described Starbucks’ provision of racial bias training to its employees. This training was initiated in response to an earlier incident that received significant national attention, sparking political debates in Philadelphia. Pre-testing indicated that this incident increased the salience of racial divisions but did not suggest anything pertinent about the ability of African Americans as economic actors. Comparing the evaluations of the non-Black and Black founders by respondents in the primed state to those in the unprimed condition allows us to determine how increasing the salience of racial divisions affects economic assessments. 
   In the experiment we will use Prolific to assemble a balanced panel of white and Black respondents.  The object of this experiment is to test H1 & H2 and to determine whether a) there is a penalty that arises post-event and b) whether this is predominantly motivate by out-group bias.  
To test the second DV (time decay), 1 hr after completion of the task we will "reveal" to 50% of the respondents that the work was done to assist two Black or White men in creating a database.  We will then ask them if they would like to be informed about any future work opportunities for us.  The remaining 50% will be sent the same notice 4hrs after completion (rather than 1hr).  The comparison involves looking at whether people who believe they worked for Black men, and received the prime, are more willing to do the work the further they get from the prime itself.

q9.value: We will be doing block randomization to ensure that there is balance between the white and black respondents.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: This experiment is designed to supplement prior work (done before we considered pre-registering), however we have not collected data for the experiment described here.

question.value: We will use an external service to recruit our sample (to ensure we have a balance of black and white respondents).  We will drop any respondents that fail the manipulation check, attempt to repeat the experiment, or answer all the questions in less than 2 minutes.

q13.value: We will recruit 800 respondents for the experiments.

q14.value: We are only limited by our resources, but the design is a 2x2 for one DV and a 2x2x2 for the 2nd, this will allow us ~100 respondents/condition, which is a minimum.

question.value: We consider three specific measures of founder quality: (1) perceived quality, (2) likelihood you would support the project, and (3) likelihood others would support the project. These attitudinal measures are borrowed from prior research on bias in crowdfunding (Younkin & Kuppuswamy, 2017) to allow for easier interpretation and comparison of results.
We will analyze the results using both ANOVA and OLS models that control for observed differences between respondents.
